title: Everybody Arts!
body:
Hey everyone!

Welcome to the Story & Art board!

I wanted to take some time to discuss this board from the standpoint of art. A lot of teams at Riot are touched by art in some way or another. There's a lot of disciplines working together all the time to create awesome content. Some of the components of the Art Team are:

* Concept - Usually 2D artists in charge of the idea phase of an asset. Concept artists work on everything from character creation, to environment design, UI and illustration. They help flesh out our world and design the next new thing, or reinvent the old.

* 3D Character - 3D artists who work in Zbrush, Maya and other programs to built and texture the character models you see in game. Whether they be champions, skins, creatures, or anything that's a life form, these guys make it into an actual thing.

* 3D Environment - 3D artists who make our maps in which our characters live in. They use the same tools as character artists to build the world that the game is played in. They set the stage for our characters to stand on.

* Animation - Animators bring static objects to life. Anything that has to move is moved by them. Characters that run, creatures who hop, structures that crumble. If it moves, our animators made it do so.

* VFX - Visual Effects Artists, sometimes referred to as Particle Artists, are responsible for our effects in the game. Whether they come from a character, a prop, a creature, or an item. VFX artists make the spells fly.

* Motion Graphics - MoGraph artists bring our login screens to life. They make our mana bars bubble, our logos move and generally make a ton of awesome. They weave spells which I still don't understand to move 2D assets and make them live.Â 

* **LOTS OF OTHER ARTISTS** - We never want to leave anyone out, but we have a ton of amazing people who work in the Art Team, and I may be forgetting some. Hopefully they'll come smack me on the back of the head if I forget them.

For art discussions in this board, here's what we'd like to do! Generally this is a place where we'd like to host discussions about art in League of Legends. This means that this is the place to discuss such things as, but not limited to:

**Character design:** How our champions, skins, creatures or other characters look and feel.

**Art process:** How we go about designing, creating and bringing to life the things you see in League of Legends.

**Feedback:** You letting us know what you think, and us letting you know why we do the things we do. A two-way street for us to jam.

Those are just a few topics that can be encompassed in this board. If you want to know how we make art, this is the place to find out!! If you notice a mistake, feel passionate about a direction we've taken, or just want to discuss art in general, here's your place! Promoting a respectful and engaging place for our artists to post and our players to ask, discuss, or just hang out.

As a side note, skin and champion concepts should be posted elsewhere on the Boards. We love your art and ideas; however, please share them on the Skins & Champion Concepts board!

With all that said, welcome!

I like this board, its gonna be nice to go to an open forum place where summoners can talk to rioters about how their favorite characters/environments are created. And, this isn't going to be a champion creation type forum is it? Where people are posting champion + skin ideas all over town, not that that is bad. I am just wondering.

We'd prefer that Champion/Skins concepts go on the Skins & Champion Concepts board. That's a better place to have a broad ideation discussion. This board is definitely meant to be a player line to the devs and the devs to the players. 

Glad you're excited!

So would you say that this is more for re-creations of what is already a thing (i.e. fan art of already-skins, what we feel are improvements on character models, etc?), or is this more about creating art that is lore based like an exploration through the Yordleville or a creepy excavation of a long-dead emperor's tomb?

It's the discussion of anything that is directly related to any art/story aspect of League of Legends in the past, present and future development of things therein.  Not so much a place to put skin ideas or champion concepts. Nor really a place to put fanfiction. Discussions about Art and Story as it pertains to League as it currently or will be practically executed is what we're setting up here. 

Fan art would be appropriate, let's say, if someone is proposing how an existing champion could be overhauled. However, a skin suggestion from a player, not so much. That can go in the player-made concepts board.

Do all fan-made things go in this player-made concepts board (assuming they're viewer/age friendly, of course)? And if so, that board has yet to be publicly visible but will be accessible some time in the future? It would be a shame for all that creativity to die out :(

Okay, cool. That is what I thought. Man, I am so happy Riot has been more player involved in the recent months, not that you guys weren't already, but it just seems like the player to company link is getting stronger with every waking moment.

What is the process for coming up with a Champion?  Is that strictly up to designers, or do other departments have equal say?

EDIT: In terms of actual green-lighting of a Champion, not necessarily a finalized Champion's direction.
Everyone has an equal say. Everyone from the 3 disciplines involved to other people outside of the direct production. It's a very holistic process.
Why remove the ghosts from SR update map? I have yet to play, but already miss them ð

If by ghosts you mean the wraith camp, we wanted to make sure that the creatures that inhabited SR felt appropriate to the magic-forest vibe that SR has... things that feel like "beasts" or otherwise feel like the jungle could be their power source. Wraiths are a cool monster, but they feel much more at home on a haunted map like Twisted Treeline. That was basically our reasoning, AFAIK.
Any plans to update the jungle creeps on Treeline eventually?
I don't know of specific plans to. We're interested in improving visuals across the board, so I guess I'd agree with "eventually." I have no idea where it falls in the priorities tho.

> If by ghosts you mean the wraith camp, we wanted to make sure that the creatures that inhabited SR felt appropriate to the magic-forest vibe that SR has... things that feel like "beasts" or otherwise feel like the jungle could be their power source. Wraiths are a cool monster, but they feel much more at home on a haunted map like Twisted Treeline. That was basically our reasoning, AFAIK.

but ghosts in a forest is a normal thing and the new dragon as its appearance is now doesnt look like it belongs either

Can you describe how the new dragon feels out of place with the new SR? Interested in what feels off there.

Also I guess ghosts can exist in forests, but I would still argue they'd feel better in a haunted / spooky forest, which isn't what I think of when I think of SR. Does that make sense?

> Can you describe how the new dragon feels out of place with the new SR? Interested in what feels off there.
> 
> Also I guess ghosts can exist in forests, but I would still argue they'd feel better in a haunted / spooky forest, which isn't what I think of when I think of SR. Does that make sense?

yeah the wraith thing is debatable.

as for dragon his coloration and style seems like it would be a better fit for something like magma chamber-esque map over rift.

I'd wager that, to some people, the new dragon feels a bit *too* menacing (truthfully, this was my first impression to a lesser degree). However, I think that's a good thing. It nods towards the notion that it's a much more powerful monster. The same goes for Baron Nashor!

Having those bigger, meaner beasts roaming SR gives them an air of dominance among the other creatures. Now, to me, that's an accurate representation *and* it's neat looking. That being said, I hope dragon doesn't get changed up, TBH.

May I ask why you decided to keep the wolfes? Not that they wouldn't fit and they obviously feel like beasts, but they just seem to be the most generic of all the jungle monsters. This isn't necessarily bad, I was just wondering since the concept art you guys showed off at Gamescom had some incredibly cool concepts. The Nut Warrior and that carnivorous plant thingy for example, among others, rocked and I am pretty sure they would make an awesome camp. Is it for the nostalgia factor?

I don't remember all the alternatives we considered, but I do know that some interpretations we tried felt to "alien" or "mutated" for the nature-vibe we wanted. Granted, we do have a two-headed wolf now... so some of that got in. We wanted the wolves to be a bit more memorable and unique, but at their core I think they're successful. They stick with the theme, they feel like they match how hard they are to kill, and they gave a decent real-world touchstone for how people understand them. ("they're a wolf pack - I understand why they're dangerous and why they're together in this forest.") Could we have gone a new direction and pushed it to something more fantasy? Probably. Maybe that would have been a good call, but I do think having a few camps stay thematically similar to the old SR helps the transition.

But who made the visuals for the Shurima videos? :) I still can't get over how perfect these looked. I watched the videos over and over again in fullscreen HD to make myself a new desktop wallpaper. :D

I thought it was very well thought, it felt like an old legend was told (and screw these guys on reddit who think Nasus doesn't know how to speak- i loved how it sounded) and the visuals were absolutely perfect for this - it was like some historical murals/mosaics/... except way better (and the camera movements, and the lighting effects... yeah, I could talk about how much i loved it for hours).

Well. All this to say that Riot artists, you're doing a very, very good job.

Also, ever since I started playing LoL (one year now) I've been trying to find the names of Riot artists (to find more blogs/galleries to please my eyes) but most of the times, they're not credited and I only know who they are when they post the work they did for Riot on their website.
Would that be possible to know who painted x splash once it's released? :)
Oh, thats some idea there with those artists's names! I spend  like hours searching through tumblr and deviantart to find them and this would be much easier... :)

I'm going to say that I really love the new look of the updated rift, but there is something I view as an issue. The dragon looks like less of a dragon and more like a "magma griffon" in terms of color scheme and design. The torso is the area I am most concerned with, seeing as it looks similar to the body of a lion and less of what I interpret as a flying reptilian monster with the ability to shoot flames.
TLDR: more scales = more dragon IMO

We are definitely trying to create something that feels distinct to League. I think that there is an argument to be made that we weren't very successful on that front, but the fact that it feels too distinct is ok to me. Could you expand a little more about what you would like to see in this creature. Dragon is a huge family of fantasy creatures.

I think a larger emphasis on the scales of the dragon can go a long way in making him look more fierce. Placing scales on the torso can give a more aggressive look to the dragon and intimidate those who dare go toe-to-toe with him. I would like to be intimidated by just the appearance of the dragon, before I witness the brutal onslaught of flame based attacks he has in store for me as I desperately try to slay it and reward my team with the spoils of my victory.

Probably been asked before, but doing game art is something I've taken an interest in. I used to do art years ago, but stopped(and I kick myself every day for it.) What would you say are important skills and can you provide any resources?

Very strong traditional skills are the keystone to any art discipline. The best advice I could give would be to carry a sketchbook with you at all times and draw in it every day as often as you can, and find a public forum where you can get feedback.
